thread.title: New England weather is getting bad. Then it'll get worse
thread.title_full: New England weather is getting bad. Then it'll get worse

title: New England weather is getting bad. Then it'll get worse
text:
Northeast braces for blizzard as coastal front intensifies By Azadeh Ansari and Michael Guy, CNN Updated 0917 GMT (1717 HKT) February 13, 2017 
Chat with us in Facebook Messenger. Find out what's happening in the world as it unfolds. Another winter blast of snow and strong winds moved into the Northeast on Sunday. Story highlights Flights canceled at Portland, ME, airport for 24 hours NNWS: Bay Area has wettest winter in over 100 years (CNN) New England drivers could be in for a dangerous Monday morning commute as a slushy mix of sleet, snow and freezing rain coats the roads ahead of yet another blizzard, officials said. The National Weather Service issued a winter storm warning for nearly 12.5 million people Sunday evening stretching from Central New York to Maine. In anticipation of the winter storm, Portland International Jetport in Portland, Maine, canceled all flights for 24 hours, from Sunday at 8 p.m. to Monday at 8 p.m. As a coastal front intensifies, freezing temperatures, cooler air and more snow are expected for Connecticut up through Maine until Tuesday evening, meteorologists said. In Maine, 345,000 people remain under a blizzard warning through Tuesday morning, the agency warns. Overnight, the colder air will move in dropping temps below freezing. This will result in refreezing of any snowpack & a slick Monday AM. pic.twitter.com/VxnWEGh2g3 — NWS Boston (@NWSBoston) February 13, 2017 Read More Boston residents could see 6 to 10 inches of snow by daylight Monday, while parts of Maine could see as much as 24 inches of snow. Wind gusts of up to 55 mph through Monday evening could cause power outages from downed trees, officials said. Conditions will begin to improve for Boston as the storm moves up the coastline towards Portland by Monday evening. West Coast gets drenched The West Coast continues to grapple with rapid snow melt and heavy rains in the Sierra mountains, which led to flooding in parts of Nevada and Southern California last week. In Northern California, recent rainfall totals have reached record highs in the Bay Area. The National Weather Service has called this the wettest winter season there in more than 100 years. Rainfall totals for North San Francisco #BayArea #Napa #Kentfield wettest winter season - to date - in over 100 years #SanRafael 2nd wettest pic.twitter.com/QzUSvXftOX — NWS Bay Area (@NWSBayArea) February 12, 2017 The service issued a flood warning Monday for Northern California for residents of Redding down through Modesto. To help disperse the water build-up in the area, officials opened the Oroville Dam's the emergency spillway for the first time Sunday. The Oroville Dam is the tallest dam in the United States. Alarm bells went off after authorities found a hole in the dam's spillway. Nearly 200,000 residents living downstream from the dam were forced to evacuate their homes Sunday. Hazardous situation is developing with the #OrovilleDam Dam auxiliary spillway. Flash Flood Warning issued. #CAwx pic.twitter.com/8k4389BY1O — NWS Sacramento (@NWSSacramento) February 13, 2017 A plan is currently in place to employ helicopters to drop rocks into a crevice atop the erosion, which would plug the hole. Thankfully, the area will remain dry throughout the week until the next storm system begins to move out of the Pacific on Thursday, meteorologists said.
